content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												There is not much good action adventure slashers on PC, as a matter of fact there is not much of them at all(on PC). Till now I remember Legecy of Kain series, Prince of Persia(sands of time trilogy) and quite new Darksiders 1 & 2, there is also DMC series which am not familiar with, yet.Comparing Castlevania LotS:+plot There is great story, with few but interesting characters, a lot of additional content(to be read ). And most of all great story telling by Patric Stewart. Personally I could only compare this plot to the Legacy of Kain series which has quite similar world and great plot also. +Puzzles In first chapter I was afraid that there won't be puzzles at, when I stumbled across first one I was not impress. But during whole game puzzles become more complex, harder and more interesting, with great vampire chess at first place, this is also big advantage of this game.There is less puzzles than in PoP or LoK, but they are harder and more sophisticated. From possible cons this become one of the major pros of this game. +Combat First thing which I may not like in this game. There is a lot of Combos, but these are not very effective(visually and practically). attacks with magic are ok, but they are limited and keybord input lag which I and lot of PC players had didn't help with performing them.Pop and LoK combat system ware much simpler but I personally prefer one from Darksiders series which was almost perfect. +Graphic, level design and overall visual experience Generally graphics  are beautiful, it of course can't be compared to PC's FPS shooters, but it please the eye. Level designs are great and varied, similar to those in LoK but both games had resembledark fantasy universes.  +Music, voice. I fall in love into "Belmont's Journey theme". But whole soundtrack is absolutely amassing and epic. It fits this game perfectly.Voice acting is also definitely pros of this game. Some major cons, as I wrote above combat system could be better. Levels between beginning and end of many chapters are just boring because most of the actual story is at the ends of the chapters.As a conclusion well this is just epic game. All action-adventure games and slashers fans should go for it.PC port could be better thou. I used to playing this kind of games on keybord, but input lag was...annoying, especially in 2nd DLC boss(If you know what I mean :))

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												I'd never played a game with this sort of combat before, and I'd never wanted to either. However, something about the story that was glimpsed at in the sequels trailer made me vastly interested in getting LoS1 to experience the interesting story, despite my lack of interest in the combat type. Lucky for me I got gifted a copy for xmas as a thank you for gifting a game to a friend. Best random videogame gift ever! I loved this game ...right after I'd re-mapped most of the controls.The games story is mildly slow to start, but the layers and details are added slowly, bit by bit and I found it really drawing me into it, immersing me in the plight of the main characters. Once I got my head around the combat, I kind of enjoyed it, much to my suprise, though I was operating on the lowest difficultly as I'm a complete novice to this sort of combat in games. At times I found the game to be quite challenging, and the that was on the lowest difficultly, so some more hardcore gamers might get some fun out of that. I'm not a big fan of puzzles usually, and they pop up quite a bit in the game, which will cater to some people's tastes. I can't complain too much though, because you can sacrifice exp gain to find solutions to them or to skip some meaning players that don't enjoy puzzles aren't forced to do something they really don't like.The game is very long and even madly rushing it because you're so envoloped in the story takes a considerable amount of time to reach completion. There are some things that can only be unlocked in levels that you gain access to in later sections of the game. This is supposed to add to replay value, ...and I suppose it would, not for and incentive to play the whole game again, maybe to help enjoy on another play through simply inspired for a love of the interesting story.Despite all my praise, I have one small issue to raise, that can cause rather big problems. It's a console port and one, that means the default controls are awkward, ..but no big issue, just remap them, but the second point is the part that's pretty annoying. The analogue sticks of controllers are brought into play in a few places during the game, ...a few places where smooth, fast and fluid circular motion has to achieved quite precisely in order to complete something/move on. With a controller this is so much easier as I found out i desperate frustration fighting a boss by resorting to plugging a wired xbox controller into my PC. The problem is the movement from analogue stick has smooth transition between directions, but WASD at certain parts of a full circle rotation that has to be executed perfectly in time and synchronisation, becomes jarred and awkward when combined with another annoying feature of the game, forced camera angles. when trying to pivot the character on a spot using WASD it's hard to transition from one part of the turn to the next, not being being clear when to start or stop pressing one of the directions to stop yourself failing the move or going backwards or simply jarring out all weird. Still it's a minor complaint and will affect only a minor portion of the game. The determined of you will get past it and those that happen to have a wired xbox 360 controller around would do well to plug it in and use that, ..the controls are nicer on it too. So if you are familiar with the controller, win, win, stick to that.I suppose also, the DLC is tiny, yet crucial to setting the plot of LoS2, it kinda feels like it should have not been optional DLC and been a part of the game considering the vastly important plot points in it. As well as that in the DLC suddenly generated cutscenes are gone and replaced with comic like visuals with narrations. It's by no means bad, but the sudden disruption in continuity and the tiny size of the DLC it does seem like the developers put the minimal amount of effort into it in order to complete it to a satisfactory level. Overall I'd definately recommend this game for it's deeply interesting religious war, sort of van helsing dark feel to it and it's great story, paired with a fun, but my no means new, take on combat and the sheer size of the content in the game. It's got at least a 8.5/10 from me.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2013
												Good game with a great story, world design and character design. The combat is very much like Devil May Cry and God of War with difficulty rivaling previous Castlevania games.  The puzzle system is the best in any action adventure game and you even have the option to skip puzzles without getting the reward. The graphics good considering the massive variety of level types. The controls are responsive and the animation is quality is really high. The entire game is highly polished, bug free and very high quality. The ending is really epic too.However there are some issues such as bad keyboard and mouse controlls and a locked camera that moves at the worst possible times making you fall from jumping platforms. The music is good but poor compared to  the previous titles that had a massive range of different soundtracks and the final DLC boss is the most annoying thing ever. There is no customisation outside of new skills and powerups but then again this game is supposed to be a reboot and the original games didn't have it until they started adding in RPG elements. There is also a ton of button pressing events which can get annoying after a while.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												1st of all for a game 4 years old (and albeit remastered) the graphics hold up very well.  I cannot praise the voice acting enough, especially the narration.  Story is strong and very enjoyable although its not your typical Castlevania story if you're hoping for that.  Gameplay is very fun think God of War style.  The only downside is camera work is not ideal but it works out fine and that its not traditional Castlevania...traditional as in you don't really explore a massive Castle, which is imo the most enjoyable part of the series for me.  Only about 1/3 of the game is spent exploring and actual vampire castle, and although I am not finished yet, that has been my favorite part.  Despite this the other enviroments you explore are beautiful and the game encourages you to go back and replay them.  All that being said I highly reccommend this game. 10/10 can't wait to move onto Mirror of Fate and LOS 2.Oh I almsot forgot the score is incredible.  Especially the calm music when you are not in battle or in danger.  Absolutely beautiful, boss music is great too and this game has many difficult and epic boss fights I know you miss from games so much.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												A good, solid hack 'n slash action game with a combat system that is as deep as you so choose.You could go through the whole game using only the basic attacks or you could use the advanced combos to tear through enemies and boss with ease. The difficulty gradually ramps up through the game, and while the common enemies will rarely give you much of a fight, it's the bosses that make this game shine. I heartily enjoyed virtually every boss fight. The puzzles weren't terribly hard but a nice diversion to keep things from being stale. Platforming elements were not too frustrating, barring one or two areas.It took me about 30 hours to finish on Knight (Hard) difficulty, which unlocks the Paladin (Very Hard) difficulty. At this time, I haven't played through on that difficulty yet, but in regards to replayability, there is a decent amount. To get 100% in this game, after you beat it you'll need to beat every level over again on the max difficulty and there is a trial that is unlocked after every level is finished that you will need to complete.At the time of this review the price for this game is $29.99, and I would recommend it at that price, and doubly so if you find it on sale which seems to occur fairly often.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
First, I would like to say that I became a fan of Castlevania through the installments on the Nintendo DS. Not only did I like the gameplay, most importantly, I enjoyed the atmosphere, art, imagery, and its mythological influences. I knew from the get-go that the gameplay in Lords of Shadow would be totally different and did expect a Metroidvania style, but I did enter the game expecting the same or similar atmosphere and imagery.GAMEPLAY (7 out of 10)The God-of-War-like, third-person, character-action style of gameplay did not put me off from the beginning like a lot of other fans; in fact, I was quite open to the change. The hacking and slashing can be as mindless or coordinated and graceful as you like, and you are given a multitude of nice, flashy combos to destroy your enemies. The implementation of Light and Shadow magic proved to be a lot of fun, and it was a decent challenge to a more strategic and coordinated balance of both to better adapt to changing combat scenarios. I found the quick-time events in this game to be the run-of-the-mill, unchallenging, pointless, uninteresting, and downright annoying combat mechanic. I had no fun with them, but that is not too big of a deal nor surprise. The Titan-class bosses in the game have a great deal of QTEs, but I only found the final one to really get on my nerves. The puzzle elements in this game were OK in the beginning, but had me pulling my hair out in the second half of the game. They were not particularly difficult nor challenging; however neither were they fun nor rewarding. These puzzles, to me, would break the pacing, flow, and rhythm of the combat I expected and wanted. Easily, the puzzles were the absolute worst part of the gameplay. Boring and tedious. Second worst? The Chupacabras (for the same reasons). I have to note that the level design was by-far very linear, but this did not really bother me; however, I do acknowledge that this is a great deviation from the great deal of emphasis previous titles put on exploration and branching paths.GRAPHICS AND VISUALS (8.5 out of 10)They look pretty damn good on PC compared to the PS3 (as expected). The world and combat looks gorgeous and detailed. My framerates were constant and high—even when there is a ton of action on the screen. I never experienced any dips or stuttering. I can only gripe about the fixed camera that is not uncommonly placed awkwardly. One nitpick I had was the character animation when Gabriel is rappelling or climbing a wall with the whip: the transition from moving to standing still is too abrupt and choppy. Aside from that, Gabriel’s movement is beautiful and smooth.SOUND (8 out of 10)I am not a diehard audiophile, but the sound effects and design were very good. Impacts sounded heavy and solid. Beasts sounded alive, hungry, and menacing. The ambient noises did their part well. The sound design in this game adds wonderfully to the game’s look and feel. The English voice acting was fantastic for the most part.MUSIC (7 out of 10)Although I found the music to be somewhere between acceptable to good, I also found it to be mostly forgettable. It definitely does not have the same punch that Castlevania music is known to have, but I am not going to fault this game because of how it compares to the music of its predecessors. In short, the music was “aight.”PLOT AND WRITING (5.5 out of 10)This was the worst aspect of the game. From the big picture, the game has some seriously awesome plot points that take place, but as I played the game chapter by chapter, I felt the story did not keep me interested consistently from the beginning to the end. It started off well, dragged and weezed in the middle, but had a stellar ending. The lore is divulged through cutscenes and from the loading screens before the stages begin. The cutscenes had decent, acceptable dialogue and writing, and they also looked and sounded fantastic thanks to their motion capture and voice acting. The loading screens made me want to stab my ears and eyes. First of all, it was pure exposition or what you could call info dumps. I prefer to be shown rather than be told. Second, the writing in these loading screens were unbearably horrendous. Think of a 13 year old trying to sound like Tolkien or H.P. Lovecraft. It was all charmless cliché, weak melodrama, and felt too try-hard. Patrick Stewart’s acting could only do so much to make these stories bearable. The game already feels disjointed from chapter to chapter (which did not bother me in and of itself), but the loading screens felt to heavy handed in telling me exactly how to feel and think about Gabriel’s current state of affairs. Nothing from the gameplay nor cutscenes made me infer anything about Gabriel that was remotely close to what Zobek was describing. I would often ask myself, “Where the hell did Zobek get that idea from?” That kind of writing in books, film, television, and games does not sit well with me at all. I found it difficult to relate to or become invested in any of the characters beyond mild curiosity.OVERALL (7 out of 10)Lords of Shadow has moderate highs and very low lows. I am very glad I played it to the end, but, damn, it really tested my patience and ability to stay awake at times. Castlevania lore-fans have a good chance of enjoying it, but if you cannot stomach the gameplay, it might be better to watch a Let’s Play or cutscene compilation online. If you come in expecting classic or Metroidvania Castlevania, you are going to be crying bloody tears. If you come with an open mind, you’re either going to have a decent time or just get bored.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												Lords of Shadow is a great game. It has great combat with tons of skills to learn and master. It has fantastic voice acting and a truly engrossing story. It has beautiful visuals and runs wonderfully. There are a very minimal amount of bugs. I once got flung up into the air and hung from an invisible ledge, but this only happened once, in one area on my second playthrough. Apart from that it's a technically solid, fun, romp through a twisted tale of deceit, revenge, and redemption. My knowledge of Castlevania is limited to this game and Symphony of The Night, but I believe this game can stand proudly as part of the Castlevania series.

												Castlevania: LoS is a very mediocre reboot for the Castlevania series. Even though the game is beautiful and the last quarter of game (including the DLC) is fun; the tedium and repetition out weigh any of the games redeeming features. The QTE's, the stunning a large creature so you can ride them only to break open something, the wall climbing, the boss fights were you do chip damage until they are stunned so you can actually hurt them, and the puzzles (even having to complete puzzles to complete other puzzles) are just too often and not enjoyable after the first couple of hours. That leads to LoS's biggest problem; the length of the game. Easily half of what you play is either unnecessary (as in its hours before you are fighting the lords of shadows or even seeing a vampire) or just there to pad time repeating the few game mechanics so the game isnt "short". I would only recommend Castlevania: LoS to die hard fans that want to see what becomes of the very first vampire hunter.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												I'll just make this a fast review from the first things that pop into my head.Thoughts:- Great Story (Predictable in some parts, but there were still surprises.)- HUGE Game (takes several hours... which is a good thing and a bad thing. Good because it is entertaining. Bad because I didn't have the endurance for that length from this kind of game and just wanted to have the pay off of the game being over.) (80+ Hours on Pokemon is one thing, 20+ hours on this game was a little much for me.)- A little glitchy (my game would freeze during some of the Baba Yaga cut scenes, and there were a few platforming glitches or lever issues)- I hate the Titan fights, but there are only a few of them- Easy game for a casual gamer to get into (I'm a very casual gamer.)- QUALITY voice acting from the main cast- Very different from your average Castlevania (You spend most of your time OUT of a castle, you don't have as many monsters, and the format of the game reminds me of Prince of Persia: Sands of Time for some reason)- Fun puzzles (except for that dumb blood cup one)- Interesting Character Design (Like, I LOVE the concept art in the game)- Gabriel is a cutie.- Graphics are pretty great too. Landscapes are gorgeous. People have a little of that uncanny valley going on. (Especially Marie. Those dead eyes...)- Really great soundtrack.- Fighting system is pretty easy to get a grip on. Combos aren't that hard to remember or figure out either.- RELICS. (I really liked the Relics along with Gabriel's super fancy cross whip thing.)Overall, I really liked this game. I would recommend it to plenty of people.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												This is my first review, but not my first rodeo.Synopsis: Gabriel Belmont of the famed Belmont family must defeat the Lords of Shadow to acquire their powers and heal the rift between heaven and earth which is allowing the forces of darkness to spread unopposed throughout the land.Overall Impression: A beautiful, epic experience strongly influenced (in my opinion) by Dante's Inferno, both the literary work and the video game. However, for those of you who have played Dante's Inferno (which was only on console I believe), this game is superior in every way.Graphics: Massive, haunting landscapes with excellent ambient effects such as rain and frost on the screen. I don't think the graphics could have been much better given the time and what the creators were aiming for.Sound: Adrenaline-driving Gothic-style soundtrack that picks up at exactly the right moments. Useful sound cues when an offscreen enemy has been spawned. Also, Patrick Stewart as the voice of Sean Connery/Ramirez (from Highlander) man. The weapons sound effects are substantial and pair well with the force feedback on an Xbox 360 controller.Controls/Gameplay: Flowing controls and somewhat simple combat/combo system which is conducive to button mashing. However, enemies usually dodge on the second or third strike so button-mashing is of limited utility.Pros: This is truly a stellar game, with immersive graphics and sound with an engrossing storyline somewhat in the vein of Dante's Inferno (both the literary work and the console game). Significant replay value for completionists.Cons: Not too many. If anything, the combo system could have used slightly more complexity to add more depth to the combat, but this may not have been feasible after everything was mapped out on the XBox controller (yes, you should definitely use one to play this game).

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												This is a great game, albeit not the best, but who am I kidding? I was constantly entertained. Yes, it takes elements from God of War and Shadow of the Colossus, but to be honest, it's because those idea works, and it still very much cut out it's own atmosphere. The action in God of War is a bit over the top (which is not a bad thing). This is still very much over-the-top at times, but it's a very different feel. The ambience is overall very different too, and the visuals (taking into account the release date) are quite good. With a custom ENB and SweetFX setting, they were phenomenol. The gameplay is very satisfying. And I appreciate being able to play Shadow of the Colussus-esque bosses because I wasn't able to on my own time, but they aren't my favorite. It's all too scripted for me. The short demo of LOS: 2 had a much better Titan battle where it was a combination of SOTC and fighting regular enemies and avoiding ranged attacks from another boss. I don't understand what people have against QTE... the reason they pop up everywhere is because they WORK, although sometimes they are overused in other games, where it seems every little action requires one. In this game, they keep you on your toes, because failing one at best gives you a loss of health. In boss fights, you will be brutally (and quite satisfyingly) killed, and I feel like I have to stay riveted to the scene so I don't miss one and get absolutely horendously murdered. I don't know many games where dying is quite as awesome as this game during the boss fights. I'm hoping the LOS: 2 continues that.The story is good, although it could have been a bit better. Comparing it to God of War, it is much better, although I'm a fan of story-driven games. Again, LOS: 2 looks like it's going to improve on this front. I like the whole descent into darkness thing, but Gabriel, as a character, is a bit lacking. His supposed transition to darkness is noticable, but not by much... he always seemed aloof and unempathetic. By the end, he's aloof, unempathetic, and a bit angrier (which is shown mostly through grimacing). I feel bad for him more when he's being described by the narrator then when I see him in cutscenes, except for a few particularly potent ones. Otherwise, he kinda falls flat.The end boss was a bit sudden, and I didn't like the design of the boss. He is not what I would visualize for that character. For a final boss battle, I would've liked something a bit more bad a** (can I swear on these reviews?) Again, I heard that's going to improve in LOS.EDIT: I didn't mention the static camera... but of course, that was a disappointment. Overall, I heavily recommend this game. However, I understand that some people might not like every aspect of it. As I always recommend, DOWNLOAD THE DEMO.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												I love this game and I hate this game.  This game is rewarding and infuriating.  This is a flawed gem that's worth playing.The first few hours of the game are abysmal and irritating.  You'll have to press through 30 minutes at a time, trying desperately not to throw your controller across the room.  You don't start with enough life or moves or idea of what the hell you're doing.  The game hasn't opened up yet.  It's 4 hours of long, drawn-out, arduous training wheels you really want to rip off but can't.  It is hellish and awful you you'll want to give up on the game.If you don't, which you shouldn't, the game opens up.  The points and skills start flowing in.  The mechanics open up.  The story gets interesting.  Everything gets better.  Everything.  It's like a switch.  It goes from horrible to wonderful in a mere hour of playtime.  It will go from tedium to joy in a matter of moments.The game is still brutally hard, even on Normal.  While the game is enjoyable and rewarding you will die a lot.  You'll be forced to rely on checkpoints like a crutch, especially during some boss fights.The puzzles are good.  They are generally doable without guides and aren't too hard.  If you've ever played an actual puzzle game these won't provide any real challenge, but they'll give you a nice break and some bonus skill points to boot.  If you are horrible at puzzles you can skip all of them.Don't expect a classic Castlevania experience.  There's some semblance of it there.. where you can go back to past levels with your existing gear and access new areas; but if you're the type of explore and poke around levels as you go the progression of your upgrades will be fairly natural; you won't need to backtrack if you don't really want to.The dynamic cinematic camera angles can be really, really irritating.  You'll get attacked off-screen by fast-moving enemies sometimes and you'll die from things you can't see.  You'll jump to places only to have the camera angle change and since you ever-so-slightly moved your thumbstick your character will whip around and fall somewhere he shouldn't, probably killing you in the process.  Words cannot describe how infuriating the camera can be, but with anything else this type of camera really just has a learning curve.  You'll figure out where to position yourself so you never get attacked off-screen again.  You'll figure out what angles to jump from to avoid untimely deaths.  None of this is really taught to you, but you'll figure it out (and die trying).Despite all of my griping about this game I still recommend it.  I really enjoyed it and I liked the direction they were going with it in for a sequel.  The story is dark and its world twisted.  There's a fascinating mix of different religious mythologies in said world that make it unique.  Despite what others might say the story is actually very easy to follow if you listen to what Patrick Stewart is narrating, read the travel scrolls you come across, and generally just pay attention.  It's not spoon-fed to you, but it's very easy to follow the plot and character development (there's actual character development!).  I think ultimately the story is what kept me interesting and going in this game.  Even when the combat gets too hard you'll want to keep going for the sake of finding out what happens to the protagonist.  He is so flawed and wonderful as a character; you'll come to care for him in a way you don't with most action game male leads.This game is weird.  It is unique.  So many of its parts are not.  The combat, upgrade system, platforming, and so many other things have all been seen before.  This is one of those games that is more than the sum of its parts.  It has a dark charm that draws you in.  This is an action game, but it is not typical for its genre.  It's like one of those 'weird' dark movies like Pan's Labyrinth that you really need to be in a certain mood to take in and enjoy.  If you go in looking for your typical hack 'n slash, typical action game, typical anything you'll get disappointed.  You'll be frustrated no matter what, but if you go in expecting something a little darker and a little more unusual it will transcend from a hateful frustration to a loving one, in the same way that you really love your spouse despite their infuriating habits and flaws that you really wish you could wave away.After finishing this game, in spite of all of my frustraton for it, I wanted more.  I am excited that the sequel to it is coming soon.  Speaking of the sequel: do yourself a favor and ignore every single piece of information about Lord of Shadows 2 that you can.  Even the promo artwork, if possible.  A major story component to the end of this game will be spoiled immediately, which really sucks.  It doesn't ruin it so much that you'll want to stop playing, though, the journey is still worth the 20 hours it will take to experience.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												I'm fan of the series since the early days, bud definitely not a hardcore one. When I saw the sale offer I didn't think twice and I bought this title without knowing what was I in for (even more, I was completely unaware that this is a series reboot). I was just looking for a fun and fast paced game and the game seemed to fit the bill, and I was 100% right. The sountrack is epic and the voice acting is the cherry on top. If you've at least seen screenshots of the early titles from the series you will easily recognise the environments as you progress over the game (and probably think of those screenshots in a different way now). I'm not saying this is "the perfect game" (the controls are a bit off at times, and the fixed camera is annoying at first), but it's extremely entertaining and feels like an interactive movie. The puzzles are entertaining, you can (and will) replay many levels  looking for secrets or trials without getting bored, the boss fights are a bit too easy at times but playing at higher difficulties or for the trials makes it harder (and sometimes frustrating if you use the wrong tactic).Bottom line: I'm looking forward to playing the sequel and I would recommend it to anybody that loves the action genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												For those not already aware, the Lords of Shadow entries of the Castlevania series are not a part of the classic continuity; Mercury Steam has crafted a total re-imagining of the Belmont legacy (including a rather big twist as to protagonist Gabriel Belmont's ultimate fate). This is not the first Castlevania game to take place in an alternate timeline, seperate from the clasic continuity, but it is probably the most ambitious among the alternate continuities. The developers did not, however, totally abandon or forget about the series' roots, and some little winks and nudges are scattered throughout the narrative (such as the reveal of how Gabriel's weapon, the Combat Cross, comes to gain the name of Vampire Killer, the name of the whip used by the Belmonts in the classic continuity. If you are a diehard fan of the original series, you may have a hard time swallowing all the changes, but if you are able to set that aside and accept Lords of Shadow as it's own experience, then you should be able to get a fair degree of enjoyment out of the story. Castlevania: Lords of Shadow is, at it's core, a standard action adventure game which does not stray far from formula. This is not, necessarily a bad thing, though, as it follows the formula fairly well. LoS is simply an example of a game which does nothing new, but does everything well. You start at point A of the stage, and work your way towards the end, fighting enemies and solving puzzles along the way. You earn experience points, which allow you to purchase more combos, and upgrade your weapons and abilities along the way, allowing you to progress further, and also to revist previous stages an access areas you couldn't before. The combat controls are fluid and work well, though you should definitely play with a controller rather than the keyboard. I know it sounds obvious, but I was forced to play the majority of the first two chapters with my keyboard, and the experience was, at best, uncomfortably passable and, at worst, nearly unplayable. Once I was able to use a controller, however, things improved a hundred fold, and the game became much more fun. If I had to cite one major complaint about gameplay, I would say that the stages are fairly linear. For someone like me, who enjoys exploration, this felt rather limiting, especially since the stages are so beautifully designed. This doesn't do much to decrease the enjoyment, however, and in fact is almost nostalgic, as this makes the game more similar to the early installments of the series, before Symphony of the Night introduced us to the "Metroidvania" style of gameplay which defined the series for so many years. On that note, you may want to brace yourself for a notable lack of castles; Tomb Raider-vania may have been a better title for this game, as you spend more time in ancient ruins and lush forests and jungles than, but that is mere semantics and not a huge issue in the overall scheme. The bottom line is this: Lords of Shadow is a solid action-adventure game with an enticing narrative, and if that is what you are looking for then you should be able to enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												I bought this game the day it released on the PS3.  At the time it was very hard to put down.  If you can put aside bias from previous Castlevania games you'll have fun with this title.  It is nothing like any other Castlevania.First time through the story drove me onward.  Gabriel Belmont is a dark hero in a dark world.  Watching the plot unfold was by far the best part of the game for me.  Many of the enviroments you visit are graphical beauties.  The combat, though I was never great at it, wasn't terrible but wasn't anything special.  My main complaint the first time through was the abseents of Castlevania-esque music.  The soundtrack isn't bad, but I'm quite a fan of older Castlevania music.  After completing the game I picked it up off and on during the next few years to play levels at a harder difficulty, collect all the extras, and complete the extra missions.  It was challenging and fun, but not the best replayability.When this game released on steam I figured I'd pick it up since I no longer had the PS3 version.  Second time through the game feels much more like a chor.  Platforming becomes frustrating and boring, along with the combat.  The story still shines, though, and demands that the game is completed once again.Overall the game makes for a sad Castlevania game, but if you let go of the past your first journy through this new Castlevania world will be a memorable one.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Had this game on PS3 and played it for awhile until the Ultimate edition became available on the PC.This versions add the DLC and of course hits the higher res and framrates of a decent gaming rig and as such is the afr better version to own!The game itself is fairly rinse and repeat once you have the basics down; its Devil may Cry or Bayonetta or any other of the games of similar ilk.What sets Castlevania appart however is the depth of lore and feel the game brings. Enviroments are stuffed with detail and feeling. The voice acting is gerenally very good which all adds to the atmosphere created in the game.There are a few niggles here and there; one later level sees you trapped in a music box and the way it is played out forces the player back and forwards on numerous occasions...the issue isnt so much the design of the level but the constant repeat of dialog and the sections within it just leaves a bad taste in your mouth after the constant forward progress of previous levels.Character design is very good throughout the game with the various enemies allowing for a bit of a mix up in the combat techniques and some nice quicktime events being thrown to the general melee on occasion.all in all a solid way to spend a few hours of mindless gaming.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 5, 2013
												Finally on PC...This was the most under rated game of 2010 on the PS3 and Xbox. I played and beat the game on PS3. The game for $30 with both DLC packs is a great value(I paid $60 for the game and $10 each for the DLC packs =$80 PS3). It has a great story line with good cinematic cut scenes. The graphics are good, the sound track and FX are good and the game play is great, but a 360ce controller is the best way to play and enjoy it. If you're a hard core gamer the paladin difficulty will challenge even the best. It's an epic Adventure with lots of Action. You start off killing Werewolves and 12 chapters later face Satan. 12 epic Boss fights, tons of creatures to slay inbetween, lots of weapons to upgrade through XP points you earn by killing creatures, lots of items to find and earn and puzzles to solve.The game has some replay value if you're after achievments, if you can get them all then your one badass botton pushin mofo gamer...For $30 you would be hard pressed to find a more fun, challenging and entertaining game. This game looks better and plays better on a PC vs the consoles it originally came out on. I usually don't say this much about a game, especially one 3 years old, BUT for $30 it's a great bang for the buck. Please don't listen to the haters, this game rocks. Most people love it...The Demo is the lowest aspect of what the game is all about. The rest of the first chapter and the other 11 chapters are really good. Play the demo first to see if your system can play it and then buy this GREAT Aventure Action Game!!! This game on sale is a huge gaming value ! I'm looking forward to Castlevania LOS 2 to come out on PC too.

												Good: Gothic, cinematic storytelling with awesome voice actors. Visceral, brutal combat clearly inspired by games like God of War. Lots of secrets hidden within the levels. Incentives for replaying levels and achieving "perfection" in those levels. Looks beautiful and runs smoothly on my not-so-modern rig. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												The first and biggest complaint I have is about the camera and it's transitions. My god are the transitions jarring and frequent, taking me out of the game every time, making me wish for control of the camera, and the fact the controls basically get stuck sometimes. I can't tell you how many times the character acted like he was hitting a wall and running along it after a transition, having to let go of the stick, then move him again is frustrating, and the platforming with a static camera was annoying, because the character doesn't turn or move smoothly, like with the camera there is no finesse in it's movements. The wall climbing just plain sucked, and I hated doing it everytime, I mean the most "intense" thing that would happen is the ledges breaking off behind you or getting away from the lava, but it didn't matter, you're stuck at one speed while wall climbing, so you just have to trundle along completely forgetting about the "impending doom" behind you. The combat at first is interesting, but after a few hours it got dull and tedious. The biggest highlight after I got bored with it, is when I figured out you could just straight us grab and kill the weaker enemies, but after a very short time, that got just as tedious. Getting yelled at to do things in a few fights by allies got old really fast. I was fighting the second Titan(collosus), and the girl kept yelling "do it now, now grab onto to something" over and over again while I was running over to do so, and other things not allowing me to focus or get into the fight, such as it was. The eviroments from what I was allowed to see were kind of interesting, and I'd of loved to look at the castle and landscapes, but you know, fixed camera and all. The story is dull, and the characters are aswell and during core games ending I laughed a bit at the portrayal of "emotion", because it just looks so stupid and bad. The eviroment has a clearly rich history and story I'd love to know about, but can't, so oh well.The "puzzles" in the game are a joke, and trust me if you've played any kind of game like this or any game with puzzles you've done these ones before.The padding is this game is ridiculous as well, the wall climbing, making enemies take more hits then necessary, the camera focused on objects/objectives for way longer than is needed, having just a swarm of enemies show up right after some platforming for no reason, then nothing as you go back to wall climbing/platforming, the motherf*cking chupacabras that get introduced out of nowhere that steal your relics so you have to chase them and get them back is terrible. They should be an optional thing to deal with after you beat the level to get a reward, not a main game element.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												I'd never played a game with this sort of combat before, and I'd never wanted to either. However, something about the story that was glimpsed at in the sequels trailer made me vastly interested in getting LoS1 to experience the interesting story, despite my lack of interest in the combat type. Lucky for me I got gifted a copy for xmas as a thank you for gifting a game to a friend. Best random videogame gift ever! I loved this game ...right after I'd re-mapped most of the controls.The games story is mildly slow to start, but the layers and details are added slowly, bit by bit and I found it really drawing me into it, immersing me in the plight of the main characters. Once I got my head around the combat, I kind of enjoyed it, much to my suprise, though I was operating on the lowest difficultly as I'm a complete novice to this sort of combat in games. At times I found the game to be quite challenging, and the that was on the lowest difficultly, so some more hardcore gamers might get some fun out of that. I'm not a big fan of puzzles usually, and they pop up quite a bit in the game, which will cater to some people's tastes. I can't complain too much though, because you can sacrifice exp gain to find solutions to them or to skip some meaning players that don't enjoy puzzles aren't forced to do something they really don't like.The game is very long and even madly rushing it because you're so envoloped in the story takes a considerable amount of time to reach completion. There are some things that can only be unlocked in levels that you gain access to in later sections of the game. This is supposed to add to replay value, ...and I suppose it would, not for and incentive to play the whole game again, maybe to help enjoy on another play through simply inspired for a love of the interesting story.Despite all my praise, I have one small issue to raise, that can cause rather big problems. It's a console port and one, that means the default controls are awkward, ..but no big issue, just remap them, but the second point is the part that's pretty annoying. The analogue sticks of controllers are brought into play in a few places during the game, ...a few places where smooth, fast and fluid circular motion has to achieved quite precisely in order to complete something/move on. With a controller this is so much easier as I found out i desperate frustration fighting a boss by resorting to plugging a wired xbox controller into my PC. The problem is the movement from analogue stick has smooth transition between directions, but WASD at certain parts of a full circle rotation that has to be executed perfectly in time and synchronisation, becomes jarred and awkward when combined with another annoying feature of the game, forced camera angles. when trying to pivot the character on a spot using WASD it's hard to transition from one part of the turn to the next, not being being clear when to start or stop pressing one of the directions to stop yourself failing the move or going backwards or simply jarring out all weird. Still it's a minor complaint and will affect only a minor portion of the game. The determined of you will get past it and those that happen to have a wired xbox 360 controller around would do well to plug it in and use that, ..the controls are nicer on it too. So if you are familiar with the controller, win, win, stick to that.I suppose also, the DLC is tiny, yet crucial to setting the plot of LoS2, it kinda feels like it should have not been optional DLC and been a part of the game considering the vastly important plot points in it. As well as that in the DLC suddenly generated cutscenes are gone and replaced with comic like visuals with narrations. It's by no means bad, but the sudden disruption in continuity and the tiny size of the DLC it does seem like the developers put the minimal amount of effort into it in order to complete it to a satisfactory level. Overall I'd definately recommend this game for it's deeply interesting religious war, sort of van helsing dark feel to it and it's great story, paired with a fun, but my no means new, take on combat and the sheer size of the content in the game. It's got at least a 8.5/10 from me.

												ok, So this game is pretty rad except for two things: 1)the two extra DLC chapters are bad. the last one is really, really bad. the controls are somehow broken(as in, gabriel suddenly decided he doesn't like my choice of direction to jump in and veers wildly off) in an area of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t platforming segments with not enough checkpoints, compounded by a boss with stupid hitboxes on all of his attacks, who moves fast enough that you JUST have enough time to dodge - IF you're on the ground. which wouldn't be a problem if you were capable of hurting him from the ground. not being able to dodge-cancel aerial attacks is one of those things that never really mattered in the main game but makes the last boss fight in the DLC unplayable. just awful. ugh.2)actually a long-standing issue with konami games... who decided it was a good idea to double-tap a direction to initate running? this is literally the worst way I've seen running implemented. funnily enough, this doesn't cause problems in the main game, and yet for the second bit of DLC causes SO. MANY. HEADACHES. because it is faster paced than the main game using an engine designed for the pace of the main game. It's been an annoyance in other games but this particular DLC has made me decide to hate whatever nebulous programmer first decided that double-tap running is a good thing.okay, after all that venting, let me get back on track- if you like castlevania, and you like God of war, the main game is a pretty solid game. it's kind of like the devs thought, "you know, there hasn't really been a good 3D castlevania...I wonder what we could really do about whip mechanics in a 3D game, though...oh yeah, God of War!"but still, stay away from the DLC. it's just. awful.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												After having played through the PS3 version of this game, having it on PC has been a wonderful experience. Super fast load times, skip cut scenes really quick and just get in to the action. It also has some unique options, such as showing your health bar near your character so it's harder to lose track, as well as health bars on individual enemies. There were more to unlock, but I haven't unlocked them yet. Personally, I enjoyed this Castlevania experience. It doesn't homage the old games very well, but it isn't supposed to. It is a *new* experience. A new origin, a new everything. And while it does take the series a gorgeous new direction, there are still throwbacks to the old games if you look for them.It's also challenging. Four difficulty modes, and individual trials to complete after each level.

I mean, wow. I’ve never been this close to vomiting, while playing a game. It constantly moves, shakes or wobbles. I’m fine with fixed positions, sometimes they’re really cool! But only if done right. If you do it wrong, the customers may come close to vomiting on their keyboards. Some will do it anyway, if only to make point.This game has control issues and doesn't trust you to do anything by yourself. Constantly moving the camera to tell you what to do and when. And always with the text. Press RT to grapple, Press RT to loot, Do this, do that. Maybe tell me once or twice. But when you feel the need to tell me for a fifth time, just stop. Please? Can we please talk about the ridicilous jingle that accompanies the text? Grrr. Patrick Steward is great. The rest is laughable. Lines are rushed and they don’t really seem to care. There might be better actors further in, but when the protagonist fails this miserably, no hope is to be regained. The visuals are great. Yay! Score one!Wouldn’t reccomend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												While the graphics can, at time, come off as looking a little rough and the combat may get slightly repetitive, this is an otherwise good reboot of a fantastic - not to mention classic - franchise.You play as Gabriel Belmont, one of the last members of the Brotherhood of Light, an ancient order dedicated to fending off the minions of the Lords of Shadow in the name of God Almighty. Tasked with journeying to an ancient forest where the power of the Old Gods still resides, Gabriel seeks the soul of his dead wife, whom the elders of his order suspect holds an important message pertaining to the Lords of Shadow and their increasing influence over the lands.Gabriel's main weapon is the Combat Cross, which is a retractable chain whip in the form of - wait for it - a giant metal cross. This provides for some relatively basic hack-n-slash combat, though they do feature some nifty combos and the cross is upgradeable. You get some secondary weapons as well, such as throwing daggers and an amulet that lets you absorb magical energy (neutral) and convert it (light or shadow) to varying effects. There is also a bit of platforming thrown into the mix that is, to be perfectly honest, neither here nor there - what I mean is, it's neither terrible nor is it particularly amazing either.Plus, it's got Patrick Stewart on narration, which is just epic!

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Lords of Shadow is one of those games that gives new life to an old school type game.  The gameplay is similar to many adventure games (Mortal Kombat Anthologies: Sub Zero is a good example) and offers nothing new.  Go here, push this button/switch, fight bad guys with combos etc. is pretty much it.  However, the story is rather engaging (Patrick Stewart!) and the environments are stunning.  Also, as a player of a lot of the older Castlevania games, I feel like there are a lot of small tributes to the previous games if one is paying attention.  In summary:PROS:More Castlevania, woot!Patrick Stewart narating the storyAwesome cut scenes and environmentsBoss fights require some thought and strategy CONS:Fixed camera angle which leads toSometimes you have no idea where to go because you can't look aroundSome places require massive button mashingIf you like Castlevania, this is a good buy if on sale. Even as a Castlevania fanbot, I don't think this game is worth $30, though. 8/10

content:
Posted: September 3, 2013
												Good game with a great story, world design and character design. The combat is very much like Devil May Cry and God of War with difficulty rivaling previous Castlevania games.  The puzzle system is the best in any action adventure game and you even have the option to skip puzzles without getting the reward. The graphics good considering the massive variety of level types. The controls are responsive and the animation is quality is really high. The entire game is highly polished, bug free and very high quality. The ending is really epic too.However there are some issues such as bad keyboard and mouse controlls and a locked camera that moves at the worst possible times making you fall from jumping platforms. The music is good but poor compared to  the previous titles that had a massive range of different soundtracks and the final DLC boss is the most annoying thing ever. There is no customisation outside of new skills and powerups but then again this game is supposed to be a reboot and the original games didn't have it until they started adding in RPG elements. There is also a ton of button pressing events which can get annoying after a while.

												1st of all for a game 4 years old (and albeit remastered) the graphics hold up very well.  I cannot praise the voice acting enough, especially the narration. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Subjective(Commonly Agreed on): This game take the one thing wrong with all 3d castlevania games and fixes it; that one thing being, the combat. Objective: Putting a more modern and comfortable twist on the classic chain whip combat by taking influence from the combat system such of god of war. Though lacking a combo counter, it is reflected on the focus meter that allows you to build mana and... (That... red fluid...lol) faster. all of what makes castlevania an excellent series is left in tact, with minor additions such as grapple, rappel and swinging mechanics. The major change though is the game structure. The game is linear yes, but you can revisit  chapters and find secrets using newly found enhancements and skills, but that is optional... no longer manditory. Subjective: I personally loved the structure of the post Symphony of the Night experience, the only way forward was back. finding an area you cannot quite get to and cannot progress until you recieve the enhancement. some find this tedious... I am in favor of it.Objective: This game harkens back to the original castlevainia games of the 90s by delivering a forward level by level srtucture. Locations are quite varied, and using UE3, present us with a world that is pleasing to the eye.Subjective: The art direction and level design capture the lore and world as a whole of castlevania in a way that we would only dream of in the 90s and early 2000s. Objective: Finding my self still playing through the satifsyingly lengthy story so far... I have experienced minor bugs. The bugs I have encounters seemed to be minor hiccups that are typical of any game. It was only rarely did I find myself completely clipping into a solid object, leaving me trapped within it for a second or two, but spamming the jump button fixes it. As well, one major important thing... the camera, though you can get use to it... jumping into the game after not playing may leave you a bit rusty in concept of remembering that you have no control of the camera. the camera, much like classic resident evil games, has fixed locations, which can switch up the directional controls upon camera switching.Overall, This is so far, The best castlevania experience  to date. As a huge fan, I am very happy with the execution of both the characters and the story. The combat was enjoyable. I found the camera to be super frustrating at times but I got use to it, but that just may be experience kicking in from classic resident evil games. The game so far reaches the epic scale. Boss Fights are epic with sime being gigantic Shadow of the Colossus experiences, and some being a head to head battle with a supernatural humanoid foe... it was quite entertaining.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Although it has a very awesome art direction, a good variety of enemies and some very intresting levels the actual level design, the combat and the story are lackluster. The platforming is linear and the controls are very unresponsive in that regard.  If there are tricky jumps or hard platforming sections, it´s because the controls aren't working as they suppose to not because of good level design. There are puzzles but they are easier than the ones found in the Uncharted series.The combat, though fuctional and responsive, is nothing to write home about. It´s very unispired and derivative. If you played Devil May Cry, God of War or Ninja Gaiden Sigma, you´ve already played this. The only intresting mechanic that differenciate this game from the much superior games it´s trying to ape is the light/dark magic mechanic. Having said that, the combat is fun. It's clear that this game doesn't want to be a Castlevania because there are sections that mimic Shadow of the Collossus but with more Quick Time Events and less Awe.The story is... well. You won't pay attention to that because you'll be distracted by Patrick Stewart's vibrating voice. It's not even forgettable because you cannot forget something you didn't understand. The worst part of this is that the main story takes about 14 hours to finish. By the end I was forcing myself to beat this crap so I could finnaly move on.It's as if Konami was trying to blend Hack n' Slashes, with Shadow of the Collossus and Patrick Stewart. What we got is a game with insipid gameplay, narcoleptic story, terrible platforming controls, and Patrick Stewart.I wasted my time playing this....

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												I saw this game on Steam for a while but could not commit to buy; the screenshots looked more like cinematics than actual gameplay, and it had been a few years since I shelled out hard cash for a Castlevania game. From what I had seen online, the series seemed to have degraded into a number of identity-confused games (are we jumping puzzles, or are we adventure, or are we 3D, or are we side-scrolling?) featuring a number of feminine-looking male heroes.Eventually I gave in while the game was on sale, and after it sat in my library for a few more months, I started playing.It turns out to be a really good game.Gameplay is fixed-camera third-person combat and exploration with an experience points system and unlockable skills and combos. The camera angles were typically well placed, though the environments hint at more exploration than what is really available.The graphics are good, with rich visuals that are a real treat for fantasy fans. I particularly liked the castle of the vampires (which is not the final destination of the game, but is the "Castlevania" of the series) and the Land of the Dead, which was appropriately eerie.This game truly shines in creating a great experience for the player. The voice acting is very good (if any of the actors and actresses are phoning in their performances in for an easy paycheck, they're too much the professionals to let it show), and the story is intriguing (though it was a little hard to follow at first).Combat is a lot of fun; the combination of interesting enemies, dynamic music, great dodges, combos, and quick-time events are woven together to create cinematic battles where the player controls the action. The first time I fought the Swamp Troll, and later when I went up against a massive golem (referred to as a Titan in this series), I knew this game was something special.On a negative note, I will say that the environments for the boss battles are very boring; with a few exceptions, you always fight a boss in an open, arena-like space. I would have liked more "swinging on my chain whip to avoid attacks" and boss battles fought over chasms and so forth.Lastly; the music in this game is AMAZING. It's possibly the best music in a video game (and many movies) that I have ever heard.I am not sure if this game FEELS like a Castlevania game. I was a big fan of the Nintendo and Super Nintendo games, and "Lords of Shadow" has a unique vibe. It's not a sequel or translation of the old stuff, but a total reinvention; this is a good thing though. If it was trying to be the original games and recycling the music and everything, it could not have shined as it does.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 15, 2013
												A great entry in the Castlevania series. Great, great story that is suprisingly deep and well-thought out with a cast of compelling and memorable characters further enhanced by excellent voice acting (by Robert Carlyle and others). As a Castlevania game there are of course puzzles which end up being rather clever and a lot of fun to solve as they are neither too complex nor too easy with only one that I found frustrating. Gameplay and combat are well done and fun with sweet-looking and powerful combos à la Devil May Cry/God of War/Bayonetta which become increasingly more badass and useful as you unlock them through an effective leveling-up and upgrade system. The enemies and environments are also epically MASSIVE at times & nicely varied and appropriately thematic as you first battle werewolves as you progress towards the lycan lord in forested areas, followed by vampires in a sinister and GIGANTIC European castle and its environs where you confront the necessary vampire master and finally a swampy area filled with zombies and its lich lord.The only short-coming I can think of it that most enemies can become easy to defeat once you unlock the faeries and especially the ultimate magic moves towards the 2nd half/end of the game, but come on, you get to ride & control bear-like lycans and huge spiders and use them to rain glorious PAIN upon those foolish enough to oppose a Belmont xD! Oh, it's also a little unfortunate that there is no element of free-roaming and that each new area is encapsulated by invisible walls or cliffs/etc as it would have been a real treat to explore the spooky and menacing landscapes but I wasn't overly bothered by this. However it really would have been nice as well as an added additional layer of immersion to the game if there were NPCs (villagers, survivors) that you could interact with and that would provide you with side-quests.9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												While the graphics can, at time, come off as looking a little rough and the combat may get slightly repetitive, this is an otherwise good reboot of a fantastic - not to mention classic - franchise.You play as Gabriel Belmont, one of the last members of the Brotherhood of Light, an ancient order dedicated to fending off the minions of the Lords of Shadow in the name of God Almighty. Tasked with journeying to an ancient forest where the power of the Old Gods still resides, Gabriel seeks the soul of his dead wife, whom the elders of his order suspect holds an important message pertaining to the Lords of Shadow and their increasing influence over the lands.Gabriel's main weapon is the Combat Cross, which is a retractable chain whip in the form of - wait for it - a giant metal cross. This provides for some relatively basic hack-n-slash combat, though they do feature some nifty combos and the cross is upgradeable. You get some secondary weapons as well, such as throwing daggers and an amulet that lets you absorb magical energy (neutral) and convert it (light or shadow) to varying effects. There is also a bit of platforming thrown into the mix that is, to be perfectly honest, neither here nor there - what I mean is, it's neither terrible nor is it particularly amazing either.Plus, it's got Patrick Stewart on narration, which is just epic!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 5, 2013
												Finally on PC...This was the most under rated game of 2010 on the PS3 and Xbox. I played and beat the game on PS3. The game for $30 with both DLC packs is a great value(I paid $60 for the game and $10 each for the DLC packs =$80 PS3). It has a great story line with good cinematic cut scenes. The graphics are good, the sound track and FX are good and the game play is great, but a 360ce controller is the best way to play and enjoy it. If you're a hard core gamer the paladin difficulty will challenge even the best. It's an epic Adventure with lots of Action. You start off killing Werewolves and 12 chapters later face Satan. 12 epic Boss fights, tons of creatures to slay inbetween, lots of weapons to upgrade through XP points you earn by killing creatures, lots of items to find and earn and puzzles to solve.The game has some replay value if you're after achievments, if you can get them all then your one badass botton pushin mofo gamer...For $30 you would be hard pressed to find a more fun, challenging and entertaining game. This game looks better and plays better on a PC vs the consoles it originally came out on. I usually don't say this much about a game, especially one 3 years old, BUT for $30 it's a great bang for the buck. Please don't listen to the haters, this game rocks. Most people love it...The Demo is the lowest aspect of what the game is all about. The rest of the first chapter and the other 11 chapters are really good. Play the demo first to see if your system can play it and then buy this GREAT Aventure Action Game!!! This game on sale is a huge gaming value ! I'm looking forward to Castlevania LOS 2 to come out on PC too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												If you're the type of person who really enjoys backtracking over the same levels two or three times (minimum), and you're really excited by the idea of never actually getting *stronger* and instead just getting more consumable gadgets to throw at stuff, then this is the game for you! If you're not the type of person to whom this stuff sounds appealing, move on. This game is plagued by a lack of imagination, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ camera angles, and even a little contempt for the people foolish enough to play it. Example: the Chupacabra. Rather than any sort of goat-sucking, the Chupacabra exists just to waste five minutes of your life. It shows up twice, steals everything but your main weapon and consumables, and then you have to chase it down -- but you never get to kill it. Or smack it. It just boogies on out of there after being a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and adds literally nothing to the overall experience. I got up to chapter nine (I think) and uninstalled it when I realized it was just going to be more of the same, especially once I finally gained the ability to double-jump (!!!) and would have to go back through six or eight previous levels to get the upgrades I was unable to reach before. That's not _fun_, that's a way to pad the "hours played" numbers. It's dull, tedious, but it's absolutely on par with the rest of the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												There is not much good action adventure slashers on PC, as a matter of fact there is not much of them at all(on PC). Till now I remember Legecy of Kain series, Prince of Persia(sands of time trilogy) and quite new Darksiders 1 & 2, there is also DMC series which am not familiar with, yet.Comparing Castlevania LotS:+plot There is great story, with few but interesting characters, a lot of additional content(to be read ). And most of all great story telling by Patric Stewart. Personally I could only compare this plot to the Legacy of Kain series which has quite similar world and great plot also. +Puzzles In first chapter I was afraid that there won't be puzzles at, when I stumbled across first one I was not impress. But during whole game puzzles become more complex, harder and more interesting, with great vampire chess at first place, this is also big advantage of this game.There is less puzzles than in PoP or LoK, but they are harder and more sophisticated. From possible cons this become one of the major pros of this game. +Combat First thing which I may not like in this game. There is a lot of Combos, but these are not very effective(visually and practically). attacks with magic are ok, but they are limited and keybord input lag which I and lot of PC players had didn't help with performing them.Pop and LoK combat system ware much simpler but I personally prefer one from Darksiders series which was almost perfect. +Graphic, level design and overall visual experience Generally graphics  are beautiful, it of course can't be compared to PC's FPS shooters, but it please the eye. Level designs are great and varied, similar to those in LoK but both games had resembledark fantasy universes.  +Music, voice. I fall in love into "Belmont's Journey theme". But whole soundtrack is absolutely amassing and epic. It fits this game perfectly.Voice acting is also definitely pros of this game. Some major cons, as I wrote above combat system could be better. Levels between beginning and end of many chapters are just boring because most of the actual story is at the ends of the chapters.As a conclusion well this is just epic game. All action-adventure games and slashers fans should go for it.PC port could be better thou. I used to playing this kind of games on keybord, but input lag was...annoying, especially in 2nd DLC boss(If you know what I mean :))

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												This is a great game, albeit not the best, but who am I kidding? I was constantly entertained. Yes, it takes elements from God of War and Shadow of the Colossus, but to be honest, it's because those idea works, and it still very much cut out it's own atmosphere. The action in God of War is a bit over the top (which is not a bad thing). This is still very much over-the-top at times, but it's a very different feel. The ambience is overall very different too, and the visuals (taking into account the release date) are quite good. With a custom ENB and SweetFX setting, they were phenomenol. The gameplay is very satisfying. And I appreciate being able to play Shadow of the Colussus-esque bosses because I wasn't able to on my own time, but they aren't my favorite. It's all too scripted for me. The short demo of LOS: 2 had a much better Titan battle where it was a combination of SOTC and fighting regular enemies and avoiding ranged attacks from another boss. I don't understand what people have against QTE... the reason they pop up everywhere is because they WORK, although sometimes they are overused in other games, where it seems every little action requires one. In this game, they keep you on your toes, because failing one at best gives you a loss of health. In boss fights, you will be brutally (and quite satisfyingly) killed, and I feel like I have to stay riveted to the scene so I don't miss one and get absolutely horendously murdered. I don't know many games where dying is quite as awesome as this game during the boss fights. I'm hoping the LOS: 2 continues that.The story is good, although it could have been a bit better. Comparing it to God of War, it is much better, although I'm a fan of story-driven games. Again, LOS: 2 looks like it's going to improve on this front. I like the whole descent into darkness thing, but Gabriel, as a character, is a bit lacking. His supposed transition to darkness is noticable, but not by much... he always seemed aloof and unempathetic. By the end, he's aloof, unempathetic, and a bit angrier (which is shown mostly through grimacing). I feel bad for him more when he's being described by the narrator then when I see him in cutscenes, except for a few particularly potent ones. Otherwise, he kinda falls flat.The end boss was a bit sudden, and I didn't like the design of the boss. He is not what I would visualize for that character. For a final boss battle, I would've liked something a bit more bad a** (can I swear on these reviews?) Again, I heard that's going to improve in LOS.EDIT: I didn't mention the static camera... but of course, that was a disappointment. Overall, I heavily recommend this game. However, I understand that some people might not like every aspect of it. As I always recommend, DOWNLOAD THE DEMO.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												I love this game and I hate this game.  This game is rewarding and infuriating.  This is a flawed gem that's worth playing.The first few hours of the game are abysmal and irritating.  You'll have to press through 30 minutes at a time, trying desperately not to throw your controller across the room.  You don't start with enough life or moves or idea of what the hell you're doing.  The game hasn't opened up yet.  It's 4 hours of long, drawn-out, arduous training wheels you really want to rip off but can't.  It is hellish and awful you you'll want to give up on the game.If you don't, which you shouldn't, the game opens up.  The points and skills start flowing in.  The mechanics open up.  The story gets interesting.  Everything gets better.  Everything.  It's like a switch.  It goes from horrible to wonderful in a mere hour of playtime.  It will go from tedium to joy in a matter of moments.The game is still brutally hard, even on Normal.  While the game is enjoyable and rewarding you will die a lot.  You'll be forced to rely on checkpoints like a crutch, especially during some boss fights.The puzzles are good.  They are generally doable without guides and aren't too hard.  If you've ever played an actual puzzle game these won't provide any real challenge, but they'll give you a nice break and some bonus skill points to boot.  If you are horrible at puzzles you can skip all of them.Don't expect a classic Castlevania experience.  There's some semblance of it there.. where you can go back to past levels with your existing gear and access new areas; but if you're the type of explore and poke around levels as you go the progression of your upgrades will be fairly natural; you won't need to backtrack if you don't really want to.The dynamic cinematic camera angles can be really, really irritating.  You'll get attacked off-screen by fast-moving enemies sometimes and you'll die from things you can't see.  You'll jump to places only to have the camera angle change and since you ever-so-slightly moved your thumbstick your character will whip around and fall somewhere he shouldn't, probably killing you in the process.  Words cannot describe how infuriating the camera can be, but with anything else this type of camera really just has a learning curve.  You'll figure out where to position yourself so you never get attacked off-screen again.  You'll figure out what angles to jump from to avoid untimely deaths.  None of this is really taught to you, but you'll figure it out (and die trying).Despite all of my griping about this game I still recommend it.  I really enjoyed it and I liked the direction they were going with it in for a sequel.  The story is dark and its world twisted.  There's a fascinating mix of different religious mythologies in said world that make it unique.  Despite what others might say the story is actually very easy to follow if you listen to what Patrick Stewart is narrating, read the travel scrolls you come across, and generally just pay attention.  It's not spoon-fed to you, but it's very easy to follow the plot and character development (there's actual character development!).  I think ultimately the story is what kept me interesting and going in this game.  Even when the combat gets too hard you'll want to keep going for the sake of finding out what happens to the protagonist.  He is so flawed and wonderful as a character; you'll come to care for him in a way you don't with most action game male leads.This game is weird.  It is unique.  So many of its parts are not.  The combat, upgrade system, platforming, and so many other things have all been seen before.  This is one of those games that is more than the sum of its parts.  It has a dark charm that draws you in.  This is an action game, but it is not typical for its genre.  It's like one of those 'weird' dark movies like Pan's Labyrinth that you really need to be in a certain mood to take in and enjoy.  If you go in looking for your typical hack 'n slash, typical action game, typical anything you'll get disappointed.  You'll be frustrated no matter what, but if you go in expecting something a little darker and a little more unusual it will transcend from a hateful frustration to a loving one, in the same way that you really love your spouse despite their infuriating habits and flaws that you really wish you could wave away.After finishing this game, in spite of all of my frustraton for it, I wanted more.  I am excited that the sequel to it is coming soon.  Speaking of the sequel: do yourself a favor and ignore every single piece of information about Lord of Shadows 2 that you can.  Even the promo artwork, if possible.  A major story component to the end of this game will be spoiled immediately, which really sucks.  It doesn't ruin it so much that you'll want to stop playing, though, the journey is still worth the 20 hours it will take to experience.

												I'm fan of the series since the early days, bud definitely not a hardcore one. When I saw the sale offer I didn't think twice and I bought this title without knowing what was I in for (even more, I was completely unaware that this is a series reboot). I was just looking for a fun and fast paced game and the game seemed to fit the bill, and I was 100% right. The sountrack is epic and the voice acting is the cherry on top. If you've at least seen screenshots of the early titles from the series you will easily recognise the environments as you progress over the game (and probably think of those screenshots in a different way now). I'm not saying this is "the perfect game" (the controls are a bit off at times, and the fixed camera is annoying at first), but it's extremely entertaining and feels like an interactive movie. The puzzles are entertaining, you can (and will) replay many levels  looking for secrets or trials without getting bored, the boss fights are a bit too easy at times but playing at higher difficulties or for the trials makes it harder (and sometimes frustrating if you use the wrong tactic).Bottom line: I'm looking forward to playing the sequel and I would recommend it to anybody that loves the action genre.
